text: THE SWORD OF WELLERAN AND OTHER STORIES
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

text: By Lord Dunsany

text: DEDICATED
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with deep gratitude to those few, known to me or unknown,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: who have cared for either of my former books, "The Gods of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Pegana," "Time and the Gods."
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

text: The Sword of Welleran
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Where the great plain of Tarphet runs up, as the sea in estuaries,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: among the Cyresian mountains, there stood long since the city of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Merimna well-nigh among the shadows of the crags.  I have never seen
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a city in the world so beautiful as Merimna seemed to me when first
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I dreamed of it.  It was a marvel of spires and figures of bronze,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and marble fountains, and trophies of fabulous wars, and broad
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: streets given over wholly to the Beautiful.  Right through the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: centre of the city there went an avenue fifty strides in width, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: along each side of it stood likenesses in bronze of the Kings of all
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the countries that the people of Merimna had ever known.  At the end
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of that avenue was a colossal chariot with three bronze horses
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: driven by the winged figure of Fame, and behind her in the chariot
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the huge form of Welleran, Merimna's ancient hero, standing with
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: extended sword.  So urgent was the mien and attitude of Fame, and so
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: swift the pose of the horses, that you had sworn that the chariot
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was instantly upon you, and that its dust already veiled the faces
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the Kings.  And in the city was a mighty hall wherein were stored
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the trophies of Merimna's heroes.  Sculptured it was and domed, the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: glory of the art of masons a long while dead, and on the summit of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dome the image of Rollory sat gazing across the Cyresian
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountains towards the wide lands beyond, the lands that knew his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sword.  And beside Rollory, like an old nurse, the figure of Victory
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sat, hammering into a golden wreath of laurels for his head the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: crowns of fallen Kings.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Such was Merimna, a city of sculptured Victories and warriors of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bronze.  Yet in the time of which I write the art of war had been
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: forgotten in Merimna, and the people almost slept.  To and fro and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: up and down they would walk through the marble streets, gazing at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: memorials of the things achieved by their country's swords in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hands of those that long ago had loved Merimna well.  Almost they
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slept, and dreamed of Welleran, Soorenard, Mommolek, Rollory,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Akanax, and young Iraine.  Of the lands beyond the mountains that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lay all round about them they knew nothing, save that they were the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: theatre of the terrible deeds of Welleran, that he had done with his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sword.  Long since these lands had fallen back into the possession
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the nations that had been scourged by Merimna's armies.  Nothing
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: now remained to Merimna's men save their inviolate city and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: glory of the remembrance of their ancient fame.  At night they would
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: place sentinels far out in the desert, but these always slept at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their posts dreaming of Rollory, and three times every night a guard
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: would march around the city clad in purple, bearing lights and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: singing songs of Welleran.  Always the guard went unarmed, but as the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sound of their song went echoing across the plain towards the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: looming mountains, the desert robbers would hear the name of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Welleran and steal away to their haunts.  Often dawn would come
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: across the plain, shimmering marvellously upon Merimna's spires,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: abashing all the stars, and find the guard still singing songs of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Welleran, and would change the colour of their purple robes and pale
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the lights they bore.  But the guard would go back leaving the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ramparts safe, and one by one the sentinels in the plain would awake
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from dreaming of Rollory and shuffle back into the city quite cold.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then something of the menace would pass away from the faces of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Cyresian mountains, that from the north and the west and the south
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lowered upon Merimna, and clear in the morning the statues and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: pillars would arise in the old inviolate city.  You would wonder that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: an unarmed guard and sentinels that slept could defend a city that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was stored with all the glories of art, that was rich in gold and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bronze, a haughty city that had erst oppressed its neighbours, whose
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: people had forgotten the art of war.  Now this is the reason that,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: though all her other lands had long been taken from her, Merimna's
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: city was safe.  A strange thing was believed or feared by the fierce
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tribes beyond the mountains, and it was credited among them that at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: certain stations round Merimna's ramparts there still rode Welleran,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Soorenard, Mommolek, Rollory, Akanax, and young Iraine.  Yet it was
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: close on a hundred years since Iraine, the youngest of Merimna's
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heroes, fought his last battle with the tribes.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sometimes indeed there arose among the tribes young men who doubted
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and said: 'How may a man for ever escape death?'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But graver men answered them: 'Hear us, ye whose wisdom has
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: discerned so much, and discern for us how a man may escape death
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when two score horsemen assail him with their swords, all of them
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sworn to kill him, and all of them sworn upon their country's gods;
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: as often Welleran hath.  Or discern for us how two men alone may
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: enter a walled city by night, and bring away from it that city's
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: king, as did Soorenard and Mommolek.  Surely men that have escaped
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: so many swords and so many sleety arrows shall escape the years and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Time.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the young men were humbled and became silent.  Still, the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: suspicion grew.  And often when the sun set on the Cyresian
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountains, men in Merimna discerned the forms of savage tribesmen
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: black against the light, peering towards the city.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: All knew in Merimna that the figures round the ramparts were only
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: statues of stone, yet even there a hope lingered among a few that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: some day their old heroes would come again, for certainly none had
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ever seen them die.  Now it had been the wont of these six warriors
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of old, as each received his last wound and knew it to be mortal, to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ride away to a certain deep ravine and cast his body in, as
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: somewhere I have read great elephants do, hiding their bones away
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from lesser beasts.  It was a ravine steep and narrow even at the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ends, a great cleft into which no man could come by any path.  There
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rode Welleran alone, panting hard; and there later rode Soorenard
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and Mommolek, Mommolek with a mortal wound upon him not to return,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but Soorenard was unwounded and rode back alone from leaving his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dear friend resting among the mighty bones of Welleran.  And there
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rode Soorenard, when his day was come, with Rollory and Akanax, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Rollory rode in the middle and Soorenard and Akanax on either side.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the long ride was a hard and weary thing for Soorenard and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Akanax, for they both had mortal wounds; but the long ride was easy
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for Rollory, for he was dead.  So the bones of these five heroes
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: whitened in an enemy's land, and very still they were, though they
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had troubled cities, and none knew where they lay saving only
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Iraine, the young captain, who was but twenty-five when Mommolek,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Rollory, and Akanax rode away.  And among them were strewn their
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: saddles and their bridles, and all the accoutrements of their
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: horses, lest any man should ever find them afterwards and say in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: some foreign city: 'Lo! the bridles or the saddles of Merimna's
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: captains, taken in war,' but their beloved trusty horses they turned
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: free.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Forty years afterwards, in the hour of a great victory, his last
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wound came upon Iraine, and the wound was terrible and would not
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: close.  And Iraine was the last of the captains, and rode away
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: alone.  It was a long way to the dark ravine, and Iraine feared that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he would never come to the resting-place of the old heroes, and he
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: urged his horse on swiftly, and clung to the saddle with his hands.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And often as he rode he fell asleep, and dreamed of earlier days,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and of the times when he first rode forth to the great wars of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Welleran, and of the time when Welleran first spake to him, and of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the faces of Welleran's comrades when they led charges in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: battle.  And ever as he awoke a great longing arose in his soul as
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it hovered on his body's brink, a longing to lie among the bones of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the old heroes.  At last when he saw the dark ravine making a scar
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: across the plain, the soul of Iraine slipped out through his great
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wound and spread its wings, and pain departed from the poor hacked
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: body, and, still urging his horse forward, Iraine died.  But the old
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: true horse cantered on till suddenly he saw before him the dark
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ravine and put his forefeet out on the very edge of it and stopped.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then the body of Iraine came toppling forward over the right
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shoulder of the horse, and his bones mingle and rest as the years go
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by with the bones of Merimna's heroes.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now there was a little boy in Merimna named Rold.  I saw him first,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I, the dreamer, that sit before my fire asleep, I saw him first as
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his mother led him through the great hall where stand the trophies
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Merimna's heroes.  He was five years old, and they stood before
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the great glass casket wherein lay the sword of Welleran, and his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mother said: 'The sword of Welleran.'  And Rold said: 'What should a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: man do with the sword of Welleran?'  And his mother answered: 'Men
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: look at the sword and remember Welleran.'  And they went on and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stood before the great red cloak of Welleran, and the child said:
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Why did Welleran wear this great red cloak?' And his mother
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: answered: 'It was the way of Welleran.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When Rold was a little older he stole out of his mother's house
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: quite in the middle of the night when all the world was still, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Merimna asleep dreaming of Welleran, Soorenard, Mommolek, Rollory,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Akanax, and young Iraine.  And he went down to the ramparts to hear
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the purple guard go by singing of Welleran.  And the purple guard
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came by with lights, all singing in the stillness, and dark shapes
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: out in the desert turned and fled.  And Rold went back again to his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mother's house with a great yearning towards the name of Welleran,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: such as men feel for very holy things.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And in time Rold grew to know the pathway all round the ramparts,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the six equestrian statues that were there guarding Merimna
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: still.  These statues were not like other statues, they were so
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cunningly wrought of many-coloured marbles that none might be quite
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sure until very close that they were not living men.  There was a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: horse of dappled marble, the horse of Akanax.  The horse of Rollory
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was of alabaster, pure white, his armour was wrought out of a stone
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that shone, and his horseman's cloak was made of a blue stone, very
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: precious.  He looked northwards.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But the marble horse of Welleran was pure black, and there sat
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Welleran upon him looking solemnly westwards.  His horse it was
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: whose cold neck Rold most loved to stroke, and it was Welleran whom
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the watchers at sunset on the mountains the most clearly saw as they
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: peered towards the city.  And Rold loved the red nostrils of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great black horse and his rider's jasper cloak.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now beyond the Cyresians the suspicion grew that Merimna's heroes
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were dead, and a plan was devised that a man should go by night and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: come close to the figures upon the ramparts and see whether they
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were Welleran, Soorenard, Mommolek, Rollory, Akanax, and young
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Iraine.  And all were agreed upon the plan, and many names were
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mentioned of those who should go, and the plan matured for many
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: years.  It was during these years that watchers clustered often at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sunset upon the mountains but came no nearer.  Finally, a better
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: plan was made, and it was decided that two men who had been by
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: chance condemned to death should be given a pardon if they went down
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: into the plain by night and discovered whether or not Merimna's
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heroes lived.  At first the two prisoners dared not go, but after a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: while one of them, Seejar, said to his companion, Sajar-Ho: 'See
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: now, when the King's axeman smites a man upon the neck that man
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dies.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the other said that this was so.  Then said Seejar: 'And even
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: though Welleran smite a man with his sword no more befalleth him
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: than death.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then Sajar-Ho thought for a while.  Presently he said: 'Yet the eye
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the King's axeman might err at the moment of his stroke or his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: arm fail him, and the eye of Welleran hath never erred nor his arm
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: failed.  It were better to bide here.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said Seejar: 'Maybe that Welleran is dead and that some other
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: holds his place upon the ramparts, or even a statue of stone.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But Sajar-Ho made answer: 'How can Welleran be dead when he even
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: escaped from two score horsemen with swords that were sworn to slay
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him, and all sworn upon our country's gods?'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Seejar said: 'This story his father told my grandfather
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: concerning Welleran.  On the day that the fight was lost on the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: plains of Kurlistan he saw a dying horse near to the river, and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: horse looked piteously towards the water but could not reach it.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the father of my grandfather saw Welleran go down to the river's
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: brink and bring water from it with his own hand and give it to the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: horse.  Now we are in as sore a plight as was that horse, and as
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: near to death; it may be that Welleran will pity us, while the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: King's axeman cannot because of the commands of the King.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said Sajar-Ho: 'Thou wast ever a cunning arguer.  Thou
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: broughtest us into this trouble with thy cunning and thy devices, we
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: will see if thou canst bring us out of it.  We will go.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So news was brought to the King that the two prisoners would go down
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to Merimna.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: That evening the watchers led them to the mountain's edge, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Seejar and Sajar-Ho went down towards the plain by the way of a deep
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ravine, and the watchers watched them go.  Presently their figures
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were wholly hid in the dusk.  Then night came up, huge and holy, out
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of waste marshes to the eastwards and low lands and the sea; and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: angels that watched over all men through the day closed their great
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: eyes and slept, and the angels that watched over all men through the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: night awoke and ruffled their deep blue feathers and stood up and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: watched.  But the plain became a thing of mystery filled with fears.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So the two spies went down the deep ravine, and coming to the plain
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sped stealthily across it.  Soon they came to the line of sentinels
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: asleep upon the sand, and one stirred in his sleep calling on
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Rollory, and a great dread seized upon the spies and they whispered
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Rollory lives,' but they remembered the King's axeman and went on.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And next they came to the great bronze statue of Fear, carved by
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: some sculptor of the old glorious years in the attitude of flight
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: towards the mountains, calling to her children as she fled.  And the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: children of Fear were carved in the likeness of the armies of all
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the trans-Cyresian tribes with their backs towards Merimna, flocking
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: after Fear.  And from where he sat on his horse behind the ramparts
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sword of Welleran was stretched out over their heads as ever it
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was wont.  And the two spies kneeled down in the sand and kissed the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: huge bronze foot of the statue of Fear, saying: 'O Fear, Fear.'  And
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: as they knelt they saw lights far off along the ramparts coming
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nearer and nearer, and heard men singing of Welleran.  And the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: purple guard came nearer and went by with their lights, and passed
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on into the distance round the ramparts still singing of Welleran.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And all the while the two spies clung to the foot of the statue,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: muttering: 'O Fear, Fear.'  But when they could hear the name of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Welleran no more they arose and came to the ramparts and climbed
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: over them and came at once upon the figure of Welleran, and they
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bowed low to the ground, and Seejar said: 'O Welleran, we came to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: see whether thou didst yet live.'  And for a long while they waited
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with their faces to the earth.  At last Seejar looked up towards
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Welleran's terrible sword, and it was still stretched out pointing
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to the carved armies that followed after Fear.  And Seejar bowed to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the ground again and touched the horse's hoof, and it seemed cold to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him.  And he moved his hand higher and touched the leg of the horse,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and it seemed quite cold.  At last he touched Welleran's foot, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the armour on it seemed hard and stiff.  Then as Welleran moved not
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and spake not, Seejar climbed up at last and touched his hand, the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: terrible hand of Welleran, and it was marble.  Then Seejar laughed
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: aloud, and he and Sajar-Ho sped down the empty pathway and found
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Rollory, and he was marble too.  Then they climbed down over the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ramparts and went back across the plain, walking contemptuously past
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the figure of Fear, and heard the guard returning round the ramparts
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for the third time, singing of Welleran; and Seejar said: 'Ay, you
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: may sing of Welleran, but Welleran is dead and a doom is on your
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: city.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And they passed on and found the sentinel still restless in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: night and calling on Rollory.  And Sajar-Ho muttered: 'Ay, you may
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: call on Rollory, but Rollory is dead and naught can save your city.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the two spies went back alive to their mountains again, and as
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they reached them the first ray of the sun came up red over the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desert behind Merimna and lit Merimna's spires.  It was the hour
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when the purple guard were wont to go back into the city with their
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tapers pale and their robes a brighter colour, when the cold
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sentinels came shuffling in from dreaming in the desert; it was the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hour when the desert robbers hid themselves away, going back to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their mountain caves; it was the hour when gauze-winged insects are
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: born that only live for a day; it was the hour when men die that are
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: condemned to death; and in this hour a great peril, new and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: terrible, arose for Merimna and Merimna knew it not.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then Seejar turning said: 'See how red the dawn is and how red the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: spires of Merimna.  They are angry with Merimna in Paradise and they
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bode its doom.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So the two spies went back and brought the news to their King, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for a few days the Kings of those countries were gathering their
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: armies together; and one evening the armies of four Kings were
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: massed together at the top of the deep ravine, all crouching below
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the summit waiting for the sun to set.  All wore resolute and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fearless faces, yet inwardly every man was praying to his gods, unto
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: each one in turn.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then the sun set, and it was the hour when the bats and the dark
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: creatures are abroad and the lions come down from their lairs, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the desert robbers go into the plains again, and fevers rise up
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: winged and hot out of chill marshes, and it was the hour when safety
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: leaves the thrones of Kings, the hour when dynasties change.  But in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the desert the purple guard came swinging out of Merimna with their
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lights to sing of Welleran, and the sentinels lay down to sleep.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now into Paradise no sorrow may ever come, but may only beat like
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rain against its crystal walls, yet the souls of Merimna's heroes
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were half aware of some sorrow far away as some sleeper feels that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: some one is chilled and cold yet knows not in his sleep that it is
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he.  And they fretted a little in their starry home.  Then unseen
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there drifted earthward across the setting sun the souls of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Welleran, Soorenard, Mommolek, Rollory, Akanax, and young Iraine.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Already when they reached Merimna's ramparts it was just dark,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: already the armies of the four Kings had begun to move, jingling,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down the deep ravine.  But when the six warriors saw their city
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again, so little changed after so many years, they looked towards
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: her with a longing that was nearer to tears than any that their
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: souls had known before, crying to her:
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'O Merimna, our city: Merimna, our walled city.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'How beautiful thou art with all thy spires, Merimna.  For thee we
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: left the earth, its kingdoms and little flowers, for thee we have
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: come away for awhile from Paradise.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'It is very difficult to draw away from the face of God--it is
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: like a warm fire, it is like dear sleep, it is like a great anthem,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: yet there is a stillness all about it, a stillness full of lights.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'We have left Paradise for awhile for thee, Merimna.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Many women have we loved, Merimna, but only one city.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Behold now all the people dream, all our loved people.  How
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beautiful are dreams!  In dreams the dead may live, even the long
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dead and the very silent.  Thy lights are all sunk low, they have
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all gone out, no sound is in thy streets.  Hush!  Thou art like a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: maiden that shutteth up her eyes and is asleep, that draweth her
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: breath softly and is quite still, being at ease and untroubled.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Behold now the battlements, the old battlements.  Do men defend
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: them still as we defended them?  They are worn a little, the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: battlements,' and drifting nearer they peered anxiously.  'It is not
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by the hand of man that they are worn, our battlements.  Only the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: years have done it and indomitable Time.  Thy battlements are like
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the girdle of a maiden, a girdle that is round about her.  See now
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dew upon them, they are like a jewelled girdle.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Thou art in great danger, Merimna, because thou art so beautiful.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Must thou perish tonight because we no more defend thee, because we
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cry out and none hear us, as the bruised lilies cry out and none
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have known their voices?'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thus spake those strong-voiced, battle-ordering captains, calling to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their dear city, and their voices came no louder than the whispers
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of little bats that drift across the twilight in the evening.  Then
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the purple guard came near, going round the ramparts for the first
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: time in the night, and the old warriors called to them, 'Merimna is
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in danger! Already her enemies gather in the darkness.'  But their
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: voices were never heard because they were only wandering ghosts.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the guard went by and passed unheeding away, still singing of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Welleran.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said Welleran to his comrades: 'Our hands can hold swords no
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: more, our voices cannot be heard, we are stalwart men no longer.  We
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: are but dreams, let us go among dreams.  Go all of you, and thou too,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: young Iraine, and trouble the dreams of all the men that sleep, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: urge them to take the old swords of their grandsires that hang upon
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the walls, and to gather at the mouth of the ravine; and I will find
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a leader and make him take my sword.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then they passed up over the ramparts and into their dear city.  And
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the wind blew about, this way and that, as he went, the soul of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Welleran who had upon his day withstood the charges of tempestuous
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: armies.  And the souls of his comrades, and with them young Iraine,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: passed up into the city and troubled the dreams of every man who
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slept, and to every man the souls said in their dreams: 'It is hot
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and still in the city.  Go out now into the desert, into the cool
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: under the mountains, but take with thee the old sword that hangs
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: upon the wall for fear of the desert robbers.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the god of that city sent up a fever over it, and the fever
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: brooded over it and the streets were hot; and all that slept awoke
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from dreaming that it would be cool and pleasant where the breezes
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came down the ravine out of the mountains; and they took the old
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: swords that their grandsires had, according to their dreams, for
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fear of the desert robbers.  And in and out of dreams passed the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: souls of Welleran's comrades, and with them young Iraine, in great
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: haste as the night wore on; and one by one they troubled the dreams
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of all Merimna's men and caused them to arise and go out armed, all
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: save the purple guard who, heedless of danger, sang of Welleran
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: still, for waking men cannot hear the souls of the dead.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But Welleran drifted over the roofs of the city till he came to the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: form of Rold lying fast asleep.  Now Rold was grown strong and was
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: eighteen years of age, and he was fair of hair and tall like

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Rold turned to go.  Then a great and terrible cry arose in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: chamber that whispers through the ages heard by none.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the dreams of Rold said to him: 'Thy knees are tied, thou art
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: soul of the warrior wailed among Rold's dreams, as Rold stood before
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sword.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Welleran, that once fought for Merimna, is crying for his sword in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the night.  Thou wouldst not keep Welleran without his beautiful
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fought for Merimna.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Rold broke the glass casket with his hand and took the sword,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the great curved sword of Welleran; and the soul of the warrior said
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: among Rold's dreams: 'Welleran is waiting in the deep ravine that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: runs into the mountains, crying for his sword.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Rold went down through the city and climbed over the ramparts,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desert to the mountains.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desert before the deep ravine with old swords in their hands, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Rold passed through them as he slept holding the sword of Welleran,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the people cried in amaze to one another as he passed: 'Rold
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hath the sword of Welleran!'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Rold came to the mouth of the ravine, and there the voices of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the people woke him.  And Rold knew nothing that he had done in his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sleep, and looked in amazement at the sword in his hand and said:
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'What art thou, thou beautiful thing?  Lights shimmer in thee, thou
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: art restless.  It is the sword of Welleran, the curved sword of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Welleran!'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Rold kissed the hilt of it, and it was salt upon his lips with
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the battle-sweat of Welleran.  And Rold said: 'What should a man do
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the sword of Welleran?'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And all the people wondered at Rold as he sat there with the sword
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in his hand muttering, 'What should a man do with the sword of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Welleran?'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Presently there came to the ears of Rold the noise of a jingling up
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the ravine, and all the people, the people that knew naught of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: war, heard the jingling coming nearer in the night; for the four
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: armies were moving on Merimna and not yet expecting an enemy.  And
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Rold gripped upon the hilt of the great curved sword, and the sword
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seemed to lift a little.  And a new thought came into the hearts of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Merimna's people as they gripped their grandsires' swords.  Nearer
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and nearer came the heedless armies of the four Kings, and old
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ancestral memories began to arise in the minds of Merimna's people
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the desert with their swords in their hands sitting behind Rold.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And all the sentinels were awake holding their spears, for Rollory
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had put their dreams to flight, Rollory that once could put to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flight armies and now was but a dream struggling with other dreams.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And now the armies had come very near.  Suddenly Rold leaped up,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: crying: 'Welleran!  And the sword of Welleran!' And the savage,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lusting sword that had thirsted for a hundred years went up with the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hand of Rold and swept through a tribesman's ribs.  And with the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: warm blood all about it there came a joy into the curved soul of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that mighty sword, like to the joy of a swimmer coming up dripping
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: out of warm seas after living for long in a dry land.  When they saw
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the red cloak and that terrible sword a cry ran through the tribal
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: armies, 'Welleran lives!'  And there arose the sounds of the exulting
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of victorious men, and the panting of those that fled, and the sword
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: singing softly to itself as it whirled dripping through the air.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the last that I saw of the battle as it poured into the depth
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and darkness of the ravine was the sword of Welleran sweeping up and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: falling, gleaming blue in the moonlight whenever it arose and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: afterwards gleaming red, and so disappearing into the darkness.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But in the dawn Merimna's men came back, and the sun arising to give
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: new life to the world, shone instead upon the hideous things that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sword of Welleran had done.  And Rold said: 'O sword, sword!
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: How horrible thou art!  Thou art a terrible thing to have come among
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: men.  How many eyes shall look upon gardens no more because of thee?
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: How many fields must go empty that might have been fair with
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cottages, white cottages with children all about them?  How many
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: valleys must go desolate that might have nursed warm hamlets,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: because thou hast slain long since the men that might have built
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: them?  I hear the wind crying against thee, thou sword!  It comes
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from the empty valleys.  It comes over the bare fields.  There are
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: children's voices in it.  They were never born.  Death brings an end
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to crying for those that had life once, but these must cry for ever.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: O sword! sword! why did the gods send thee among men?'  And the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tears of Rold fell down upon the proud sword but could not wash it
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: clean.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And now that the ardour of battle had passed away, the spirits of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Merimna's people began to gloom a little, like their leader's, with
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their fatigue and with the cold of the morning; and they looked at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sword of Welleran in Rold's hand and said: 'Not any more, not
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hand of another.  Now we know indeed that he is dead.  O Welleran,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thou wast our sun and moon and all our stars.  Now is the sun fallen
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down and the moon broken, and all the stars are scattered as the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: diamonds of a necklace that is snapped off one who is slain by

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: violence.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thus wept the people of Merimna in the hour of their great victory,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for men have strange moods, while beside them their old inviolate
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: city slumbered safe.  But back from the ramparts and beyond the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountains and over the lands that they had conquered of old, beyond
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord
