text: The Fall of Babbulkund
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I said: 'I will arise now and see Babbulkund, City of Marvel.  She is
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of one age with the earth; the stars are her sisters.  Pharaohs of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the old time coming conquering from Araby first saw her, a solitary
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountain in the desert, and cut the mountain into towers and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: terraces.  They destroyed one of the hills of God, but they made
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund.  She is carven, not built; her palaces are one with her
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: terraces, there is neither join nor cleft.  Hers is the beauty of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: youth of the world.  She deemeth herself to be the middle of Earth,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and hath four gates facing outward to the Nations.  There sits
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: outside her eastern gate a colossal god of stone.  His face flushes
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the lights of dawn.  When the morning sunlight warms his lips
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they part a little, and he giveth utterance to the words "Oon Oom,"
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the language is long since dead in which he speaks, and all his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: worshippers are gathered to their tombs, so that none knoweth what
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the words portend that he uttereth at dawn.  Some say that he greets
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sun as one god greets another in the language thereof, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: others say that he proclaims the day, and others that he uttereth
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: warning.  And at every gate is a marvel not credible until beholden.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I gathered three friends and said to them: 'We are what we have
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seen and known.  Let us journey now and behold Babbulkund, that our
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: minds may be beautified with it and our spirits made holier.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So we took ship and travelled over the lifting sea, and remembered
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not things done in the towns we knew, but laid away the thoughts of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: them like soiled linen and put them by, and dreamed of Babbulkund.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But when we came to the land of which Babbulkund is the abiding
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: glory, we hired a caravan of camels and Arab guides, and passed
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: southwards in the afternoon on the three days' journey through the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desert that should bring us to the white walls of Babbulkund.  And
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the heat of the sun shone upon us out of the bright grey sky, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the heat of the desert beat up at us from below.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: About sunset we halted and tethered our horses, while the Arabs
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: unloaded the provisions from the camels and prepared a fire out of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dry scrub, for at sunset the heat of the desert departs from it
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: suddenly, like a bird.  Then we saw a traveller approaching us on a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: camel coming from the south.  When he was come near we said to him:
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Come and encamp among us, for in the desert all men are brothers,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and we will give thee meat to eat and wine, or, if thou art bound by
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thy faith, we will give thee some other drink that is not accursed
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by the prophet.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The traveller seated himself beside us on the sand, and crossed his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: legs and answered:
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Hearken, and I will tell you of Babbulkund, City of Marvel.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund stands just below the meeting of the rivers, where
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Oonrana, River of Myth, flows into the Waters of Fable, even the old
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stream Plegathanees.  These, together, enter her northern gate
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rejoicing.  Of old they flowed in the dark through the Hill that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Nehemoth, the first of Pharaohs, carved into the City of Marvel.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sterile and desolate they float far through the desert, each in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: appointed cleft, with life upon neither bank, but give birth in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund to the sacred purple garden whereof all nations sing.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thither all the bees come on a pilgrimage at evening by a secret way
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the air.  Once, from his twilit kingdom, which he rules equally
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the sun, the moon saw and loved Babbulkund, clad with her
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: purple garden; and the moon wooed Babbulkund, and she sent him
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: weeping away, for she is more beautiful than all her sisters the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stars.  Her sisters come to her at night into her maiden chamber.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Even the gods speak sometimes of Babbulkund, clad with her purple
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: garden.  Listen, for I perceive by your eyes that ye have not seen
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund; there is a restlessness in them and an unappeased
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wonder.  Listen.  In the garden whereof I spoke there is a lake that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hath no twin or fellow in the world; there is no companion for it
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: among all the lakes.  The shores of it are of glass, and the bottom
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of it.  In it are great fish having golden and scarlet scales, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they swim to and fro.  Here it is the wont of the eighty-second
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Nehemoth (who rules in the city today) to come, after the dusk has
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fallen, and sit by the lake alone, and at this hour eight hundred
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slaves go down by steps through caverns into vaults beneath the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lake.  Four hundred of them carrying purple lights march one behind
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the other, from east to west, and four hundred carrying green lights
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: march one behind the other, from west to east.  The two lines cross
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and re-cross each other in and out as the slaves go round and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: round, and the fearful fish flash up and down and to and fro.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But upon that traveller speaking night descended, solemn and cold,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and we wrapped ourselves in our blankets and lay down upon the sand
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the sight of the astral sisters of Babbulkund.  And all that night
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the desert said many things, softly and in a whisper, but I knew not
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: what he said.  Only the sand knew and arose and was troubled and lay
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down again, and the wind knew.  Then, as the hours of the night went
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by, these two discovered the foot-tracks wherewith we had disturbed
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the holy desert, and they troubled over them and covered them up;
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and then the wind lay down and the sand rested.  Then the wind arose
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again and the sand danced.  This they did many times.  And all the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: while the desert whispered what I shall not know.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then I slept awhile and awoke just before sunrise, very cold.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Suddenly the sun leapt up and flamed upon our faces; we all threw
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: off our blankets and stood up.  Then we took food, and afterwards
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: started southwards, and in the heat of the day rested, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: afterwards pushed on again.  And all the while the desert remained
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the same, like a dream that will not cease to trouble a tired
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sleeper.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And often travellers passed us in the desert, coming from the City
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Marvel, and there was a light and a glory in their eyes from
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: having seen Babbulkund.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: That evening, at sunset, another traveller neared us, and we hailed
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him, saying:
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Wilt thou eat and drink with us, seeing that all men are brothers
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the desert?'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And he descended from his camel and sat by us and said:
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'When morning shines on the colossus Neb and Neb speaks, at once the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: musicians of King Nehemoth in Babbulkund awake.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'At first their fingers wander over their golden harps, or they
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stroke idly their violins.  Clearer and clearer the note of each
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: instrument ascends like larks arising from the dew, till suddenly
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they all blend together and a new melody is born.  Thus, every
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: morning, the musicians of King Nehemoth make a new marvel in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: City of Marvel; for these are no common musicians, but masters of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: melody, raided by conquest long since, and carried away in ships
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from the Isles of Song.  And, at the sound of the music, Nehemoth
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: awakes in the eastern chamber of his palace, which is carved in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: form of a great crescent, four miles long, on the northern side of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the city.  Full in the windows of its eastern chamber the sun rises,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and full in the windows of its western chamber the sun sets.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'When Nehemoth awakes he summons slaves who bring a palanquin with
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bells, which the King enters, having lightly robed.  Then the slaves
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: run and bear him to the onyx Chamber of the Bath, with the sound of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: small bells ringing as they run.  And when Nehemoth emerges thence,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bathed and anointed, the slaves run on with their ringing palanquin
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and bear him to the Orient Chamber of Banquets, where the King takes
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the first meal of the day.  Thence, through the great white corridor
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: whose windows all face sunwards, Nehemoth, in his palanquin, passes
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on to the Audience Chamber of Embassies from the North, which is all
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: decked with Northern wares.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'All about it are ornaments of amber from the North and carven
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: chalices of the dark brown Northern crystal, and on its floors lie
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: furs from Baltic shores.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'In adjoining chambers are stored the wonted food of the hardy
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Northern men, and the strong wine of the North, pale but terrible.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Therein the King receives barbarian princes from the frigid lands.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thence the slaves bear him swiftly to the Audience Chamber of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Embassies from the East, where the walls are of turquoise, studded
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the rubies of Ceylon, where the gods are the gods of the East,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: where all the hangings have been devised in the gorgeous heart of Ind,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and where all the carvings have been wrought with the cunning of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: isles.  Here, if a caravan hath chanced to have come in from Ind or
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from Cathay, it is the King's wont to converse awhile with Moguls or
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Mandarins, for from the East come the arts and knowledge of the world,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the converse of their people is polite.  Thus Nehemoth passes on
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through the other Audience Chambers and receives, perhaps, some
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sheikhs of the Arab folk who have crossed the great desert from the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: West, or receives an embassy sent to do him homage from the shy
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: jungle people to the South.  And all the while the slaves with the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ringing palanquin run westwards, following the sun, and ever the sun
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shines straight into the chamber where Nehemoth sits, and all the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: while the music from one or other of his bands of musicians comes
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tinkling to his ears.  But when the middle of the day draws near, the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slaves run to the cool groves that lie along the verandahs on the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: northern side of the palace, forsaking the sun, and as the heat
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: overcomes the genius of the musicians, one by one their hands fall
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from their instruments, till at last all melody ceases.  At this
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: moment Nehemoth falls asleep, and the slaves put the palanquin down
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and lie down beside it.  At this hour the city becomes quite still,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the palace of Nehemoth and the tombs of the Pharaohs of old face
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to the sunlight, all alike in silence.  Even the jewellers in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: market-place, selling gems to princes, cease from their bargaining
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and cease to sing; for in Babbulkund the vendor of rubies sings the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: song of the ruby, and the vendor of sapphires sings the song of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sapphire, and each stone hath its song, so that a man, by his song,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: proclaims and makes known his wares.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'But all these sounds cease at the meridian hour, the jewellers in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the market-place lie down in what shadow they can find, and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: princes go back to the cool places in their palaces, and a great
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hush in the gleaming air hangs over Babbulkund.  But in the cool of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the late afternoon, one of the King's musicians will awake from
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dreaming of his home and will pass his fingers, perhaps, over the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: strings of his harp and, with the music, some memory may arise of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the wind in the glens of the mountains that stand in the Isles of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Song.  Then the musician will wrench great cries out of the soul of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his harp for the sake of the old memory, and his fellows will awake
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and all make a song of home, woven of sayings told in the harbour
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when the ships came in, and of tales in the cottages about the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: people of old time.  One by one the other bands of musicians will
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: take up the song, and Babbulkund, City of Marvel, will throb with
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: this marvel anew.  Just now Nehemoth awakes, the slaves leap to their
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: feet and bear the palanquin to the outer side of the great crescent
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: palace between the south and the west, to behold the sun again.  The
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: palanquin, with its ringing bells, goes round once more; the voices
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the jewellers sing again, in the market-place, the song of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: emerald, the song of the sapphire; men talk on the housetops,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beggars wail in the streets, the musicians bend to their work, all
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sounds blend together into one murmur, the voice of Babbulkund
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: speaking at evening.  Lower and lower sinks the sun, till Nehemoth,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: following it, comes with his panting slaves to the great purple
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: garden of which surely thine own country has its songs, from
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wherever thou art come.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'There he alights from his palanquin and goes up to a throne of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ivory set in the garden's midst, facing full westwards, and sits
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there alone, long regarding the sunlight until it is quite gone.  At
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: this hour trouble comes into the face of Nehemoth.  Men have heard
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him muttering at the time of sunset: "Even I too, even I too." Thus
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: do King Nehemoth and the sun make their glorious ambits about
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'A little later, when the stars come out to envy the beauty of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: City of Marvel, the King walks to another part of the garden and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sits in an alcove of opal all alone by the marge of the sacred lake.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: This is the lake whose shores and floors are of glass, which is lit
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from beneath by slaves with purple lights and with green lights
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: intermingling, and is one of the seven wonders of Babbulkund.  Three
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the wonders are in the city's midst and four are at her gates.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: There is the lake, of which I tell thee, and the purple garden of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: which I have told thee and which is a wonder even to the stars, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there is Ong Zwarba, of which I shall tell thee also.  And the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wonders at the gates are these.  At the eastern gate Neb.  And at the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: northern gate the wonder of the river and the arches, for the River
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Myth, which becomes one with the Waters of Fable in the desert
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: outside the city, floats under a gate of pure gold, rejoicing, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: under many arches fantastically carven that are one with either
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bank.  The marvel at the western gate is the marvel of Annolith and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dog Voth.  Annolith sits outside the western gate facing towards
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the city.  He is higher than any of the towers or palaces, for his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: head was carved from the summit of the old hill; he hath two eyes of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sapphire wherewith he regards Babbulkund, and the wonder of the eyes
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is that they are today in the same sockets wherein they glowed when
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: first the world began, only the marble that covered them has been
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: carven away and the light of day let in and the sight of the envious
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stars.  Larger than a lion is the dog Voth beside him; every hair is
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: carven upon the back of Voth, his war hackles are erected and his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: teeth are bared.  All the Nehemoths have worshipped the god Annolith,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but all their people pray to the dog Voth, for the law of the land
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is that none but a Nehemoth may worship the god Annolith.  The marvel
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: at the southern gate is the marvel of the jungle, for he comes with
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all his wild untravelled sea of darkness and trees and tigers and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sunward-aspiring orchids right through a marble gate in the city
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wall and enters the city, and there widens and holds a space in its
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: midst of many miles across.  Moreover, he is older than the City of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Marvel, for he dwelt long since in one of the valleys of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountain which Nehemoth, first of Pharaohs, carved into Babbulkund.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Now the opal alcove in which the King sits at evening by the lake
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stands at the edge of the jungle, and the climbing orchids of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: jungle have long since crept from their homes through clefts of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: opal alcove, lured by the lights of the lake, and now bloom there
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: exultingly.  Near to this alcove are the hareems of Nehemoth.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'The King hath four hareems--one for the stalwart women from the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountains to the north, one for the dark and furtive jungle women,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: one for the desert women that have wandering souls and pine in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund, and one for the princesses of his own kith, whose brown
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cheeks blush with the blood of ancient Pharaohs and who exult with
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund in her surpassing beauty, and who know nought of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desert or the jungle or the bleak hills to the north.  Quite
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: unadorned and clad in simple garments go all the kith of Nehemoth,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for they know well that he grows weary of pomp.  Unadorned all save
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: one, the Princess Linderith, who weareth Ong Zwarba and the three
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lesser gems of the sea.  Such a stone is Ong Zwarba that there are
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: none like it even in the turban of Nehemoth nor in all the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sanctuaries of the sea.  The same god that made Linderith made long
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ago Ong Zwarba; she and Ong Zwarba shine together with one light,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and beside this marvellous stone gleam the three lesser ones of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sea.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Now when the King sitteth in his opal alcove by the sacred lake
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the orchids blooming around him all sounds are become still.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The sound of the tramping of the weary slaves as they go round and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: round never comes to the surface.  Long since the musicians sleep,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and their hands have fallen dumb upon their instruments, and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: voices in the city have died away.  Perhaps a sigh of one of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desert women has become half a song, or on a hot night in summer one
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the women of the hills sings softly a song of snow; all night
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: long in the midst of the purple garden sings one nightingale; all else
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is still; the stars that look on Babbulkund arise and set, the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cold unhappy moon drifts lonely through them, the night wears on; at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: last the dark figure of Nehemoth, eighty-second of his line, rises
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and moves stealthily away.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The traveller ceased to speak.  For a long time the clear stars,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sisters of Babbulkund, had shone upon him speaking, the desert
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wind had arisen and whispered to the sand, and the sand had long
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gone secretly to and fro; none of us had moved, none of us had
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fallen asleep, not so much from wonder at his tale as from the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thought that we ourselves in two days' time should see that wondrous
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: city.  Then we wrapped our blankets around us and lay down with our
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: feet towards the embers of our fire and instantly were asleep, and in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: our dreams we multiplied the fame of the City of Marvel.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The sun arose and flamed upon our faces, and all the desert glinted
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with its light.  Then we stood up and prepared the morning meal, and,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when we had eaten, the traveller departed.  And we commended his soul
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to the god of the land whereto he went, of the land of his home to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the northward, and he commended our souls to the God of the people
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the land wherefrom we had come.  Then a traveller overtook us
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: going on foot; he wore a brown cloak that was all in rags and he
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seemed to have been walking all night, and he walked hurriedly but
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: appeared weary, so we offered him food and drink, of which he
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: partook thankfully.  When we asked him where he was going, he
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: answered 'Babbulkund.' Then we offered him a camel upon which to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ride, for we said, 'We also go to Babbulkund.' But he answered
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: strangely:
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Nay, pass on before me, for it is a sore thing never to have seen
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund, having lived while yet she stood.  Pass on before me and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: behold her, and then flee away at once, returning northwards.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then, though we understood him not, we left him, for he was
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: insistent, and passed on our journey southwards through the desert,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and we came before the middle of the day to an oasis of palm trees
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: standing by a well and there we gave water to the haughty camels and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: replenished our water-bottles and soothed our eyes with the sight of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: green things and tarried for many hours in the shade.  Some of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: men slept, but of those that remained awake each man sang softly the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: songs of his own country, telling of Babbulkund.  When the afternoon
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was far spent we travelled a little way southwards, and went on
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through the cool evening until the sun fell low and we encamped, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: as we sat in our encampment the man in rags overtook us, having
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: travelled all the day, and we gave him food and drink again, and in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the twilight he spoke, saying:
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'I am the servant of the Lord the God of my people, and I go to do
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his work on Babbulkund.  She is the most beautiful city in the world;
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there hath been none like her, even the stars of God go envious of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: her beauty.  She is all white, yet with streaks of pink that pass
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through her streets and houses like flames in the white mind of a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sculptor, like desire in Paradise.  She hath been carved of old out
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of a holy hill, no slaves wrought the City of Marvel, but artists
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: toiling at the work they loved.  They took no pattern from the houses
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of men, but each man wrought what his inner eye had seen and carved
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in marble the visions of his dream.  All over the roof of one of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: palace chambers winged lions flit like bats, the size of every one
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is the size of the lions of God, and the wings are larger than any
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wing created; they are one above the other more than a man can
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: number, they are all carven out of one block of marble, the chamber
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: itself is hollowed from it, and it is borne aloft upon the carven
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: branches of a grove of clustered tree-ferns wrought by the hand of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: some jungle mason that loved the tall fern well.  Over the River of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Myth, which is one with the Waters of Fable, go bridges, fashioned
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: like the wisteria tree and like the drooping laburnum, and a hundred
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: others of wonderful devices, the desire of the souls of masons a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: long while dead.  Oh! very beautiful is white Babbulkund, very
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beautiful she is, but proud; and the Lord the God of my people hath
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seen her in her pride, and looking towards her hath seen the prayers
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Nehemoth going up to the abomination Annolith and all the people
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: following after Voth.  She is very beautiful, Babbulkund; alas that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I may not bless her.  I could live always on one of her inner
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: terraces looking on the mysterious jungle in her midst and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heavenward faces of the orchids that, clambering from the darkness,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: behold the sun.  I could love Babbulkund with a great love, yet am I
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the servant of the Lord the God of my people, and the King hath
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sinned unto the abomination Annolith, and the people lust
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: exceedingly for Voth.  Alas for thee, Babbulkund, alas that I may not
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: even now turn back, for tomorrow I must prophesy against thee and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cry out against thee, Babbulkund.  But ye travellers that have
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: entreated me hospitably, rise and pass on with your camels, for I
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: can tarry no longer, and I go to do the work on Babbulkund of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Lord the God of my people.  Go now and see the beauty of Babbulkund
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: before I cry out against her, and then flee swiftly northwards.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: A smouldering fragment fell in upon our camp fire and sent a strange
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: light into the eyes of the man in rags.  He rose at once, and his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tattered cloak swirled up with him like a great wing; he said no
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: more, but turned round from us instantly southwards, and strode away
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: into the darkness towards Babbulkund.  Then a hush fell upon our
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: encampment, and the smell of the tobacco of those lands arose.  When
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the last flame died down in our camp fire I fell asleep, but my rest
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was troubled by shifting dreams of doom.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Morning came, and our guides told us that we should come to the city
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ere nightfall.  Again we passed southwards through the changeless
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desert; sometimes we met travellers coming from Babbulkund, with the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beauty of its marvels still fresh in their eyes.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When we encamped near the middle of the day we saw a great number of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: people on foot coming towards us running, from the southwards.  These
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we hailed when they were come near, saying, 'What of Babbulkund?'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: They answered: 'We are not of the race of the people of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund, but were captured in youth and taken away from the hills
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that are to the northward.  Now we have all seen in visions of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stillness the Lord the God of our people calling to us from His
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hills, and therefore we all flee northwards.  But in Babbulkund King
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Nehemoth hath been troubled in the nights by unkingly dreams of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: doom, and none may interpret what the dreams portend.  Now this is
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dream that King Nehemoth dreamed on the first night of his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dreaming.  He saw move through the stillness a bird all black, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beneath the beatings of his wings Babbulkund gloomed and darkened;
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and after him flew a bird all white, beneath the beatings of whose
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wings Babbulkund gleamed and shone; and there flew by four more
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: birds alternately black and white.  And, as the black ones passed
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund darkened, and when the white ones appeared her streets
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and houses shone.  But after the sixth bird there came no more, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund vanished from her place, and there was only the empty
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desert where she had stood, and the rivers Oonrana and Plegathanees
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mourning alone.  Next morning all the prophets of the King gathered
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: before their abominations and questioned them of the dream, and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: abominations spake not.  But when the second night stepped down from
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the halls of God, dowered with many stars, King Nehemoth dreamed
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again; and in this dream King Nehemoth saw four birds only, black
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and white alternately as before.  And Babbulkund darkened again as
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the black ones passed, and shone when the white came by; only after
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the four birds came no more, and Babbulkund vanished from her place,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: leaving only the forgetful desert and the mourning rivers.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Still the abominations spake not, and none could interpret the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dream.  And when the third night came forth from the divine halls
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of her home dowered like her sisters, again King Nehemoth dreamed.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And he saw a bird all black go by again, beneath whom Babbulkund
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: darkened, and then a white bird and Babbulkund shone; and after them
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came no more, and Babbulkund passed away.  And the golden day
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: appeared, dispelling dreams, and still the abominations were silent,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the King's prophets answered not to portend the omen of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dream.  One prophet only spake before the King, saying: "The sable
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: birds, O King, are the nights, and the white birds are the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: days.  . ." This thing the King had feared, and he arose and smote the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prophet with his sword, whose soul went crying away and had to do no
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: more with nights and days.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'It was last night that the King dreamed his third dream, and this
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: morning we fled away from Babbulkund.  A great heat lies over it, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the orchids of the jungle droop their heads.  All night long the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: women in the hareem of the North have wailed horribly for their
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hills.  A fear hath fallen upon the city, and a boding.  Twice hath
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Nehemoth gone to worship Annolith, and all the people have
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prostrated themselves before Voth.  Thrice the horologers have looked
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: into the great crystal globe wherein are foretold all happenings to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: be, and thrice the globe was blank.  Yea, though they went a fourth
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: time yet was no vision revealed; and the people's voice is hushed in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Soon the travellers arose and pushed on northwards again, leaving us
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wondering.  Through the heat of the day we rested as well as we
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: might, but the air was motionless and sultry and the camels ill at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ease.  The Arabs said that it boded a desert storm, and that a great
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wind would arise full of sand.  So we arose in the afternoon, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: travelled swiftly, hoping to come to shelter before the storm.  And
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the air burned in the stillness between the baked desert and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: glaring sky.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Suddenly a wind arose out of the South, blowing from Babbulkund, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sand lifted and went by in great shapes, all whispering.  And the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wind blew violently, and wailed as it blew, and hundreds of sandy
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shapes went towering by, and there were little cries among them and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sounds of a passing away.  Soon the wind sank quite suddenly, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: its cries died, and the panic ceased among the driven sands.  And
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when the storm departed the air was cool, and the terrible
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sultriness and the boding were passed away, and the camels had ease
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: among them.  And the Arabs said that the storm which was to be had
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: been, as was willed of old by God.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The sun set and the gloaming came, and we neared the junction of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Oonrana and Plegathanees, but in the darkness discerned not
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Babbulkund.  We pushed on hurriedly to reach the city ere nightfall,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and came to the junction of the River of Myth where he meets with
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the Waters of Fable, and still saw not Babbulkund.  All round us lay
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sand and rocks of the unchanging desert, save to the southwards
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: where the jungle stood with its orchids facing skywards.  Then we
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: perceived that we had arrived too late, and that her doom had come
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to Babbulkund; and by the river in the empty desert on the sand the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: man in rags was seated, with his face hidden in his hands, weeping
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bitterly.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thus passed away in the hour of her iniquities before Annolith, in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the two thousand and thirty-second year of her being, in the six
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thousand and fiftieth year of the building of the World, Babbulkund,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: City of Marvel, sometime called by those that hated her City of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Dog, but hourly mourned in Araby and Ind and wide through jungle and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desert; leaving no memorial in stone to show that she had been, but
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: remembered with an abiding love, in spite of the anger of God, by
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all that knew her beauty, whereof still they sing.
