text: Chapter I
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The north wind was blowing, and red and golden the last days of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Autumn were streaming hence.  Solemn and cold over the marshes arose
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the evening.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: It became very still.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then the last pigeon went home to the trees on the dry land in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: distance, whose shapes already had taken upon themselves a mystery
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the haze.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then all was still again.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: As the light faded and the haze deepened, mystery crept nearer from
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: every side.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then the green plover came in crying, and all alighted.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And again it became still, save when one of the plover arose and flew
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a little way uttering the cry of the waste.  And hushed and silent
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: became the earth, expecting the first star.  Then the duck came in,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the widgeon, company by company: and all the light of day faded
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: out of the sky saving one red band of light.  Across the light
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: appeared, black and huge, the wings of a flock of geese beating up
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wind to the marshes.  These, too, went down among the rushes.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then the stars appeared and shone in the stillness, and there was
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: silence in the great spaces of the night.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Suddenly the bells of the cathedral in the marshes broke out,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: calling to evensong.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Eight centuries ago on the edge of the marsh men had built the huge
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cathedral, or it may have been seven centuries ago, or perhaps
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nine--it was all one to the Wild Things.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So evensong was held, and candles lighted, and the lights through
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the windows shone red and green in the water, and the sound of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: organ went roaring over the marshes.  But from the deep and perilous
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: places, edged with bright mosses, the Wild Things came leaping up to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dance on the reflection of the stars, and over their heads as they
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: danced the marsh-lights rose and fell.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The Wild Things are somewhat human in appearance, only all brown
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of skin and barely two feet high.  Their ears are pointed like the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: squirrel's, only far larger, and they leap to prodigious heights.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: They live all day under deep pools in the loneliest marshes, but at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: night they come up and dance.  Each Wild Thing has over its head a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: marsh-light, which moves as the Wild Thing moves; they have no
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: souls, and cannot die, and are of the kith of the Elf-folk.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: All night they dance over the marshes, treading upon the reflection
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the stars (for the bare surface of the water will not hold them
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by itself); but when the stars begin to pale, they sink down one by
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: one into the pools of their home.  Or if they tarry longer, sitting
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: upon the rushes, their bodies fade from view as the marsh-fires pale
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the light, and by daylight none may see the Wild Things of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: kith of the Elf-folk.  Neither may any see them even at night unless
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they were born, as I was, in the hour of dusk, just at the moment
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when the first star appears.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now, on the night that I tell of, a little Wild Thing had gone
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: drifting over the waste, till it came right up to the walls of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cathedral and danced upon the images of the coloured saints as they
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lay in the water among the reflection of the stars.  And as it leaped
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in its fantastic dance, it saw through the painted windows to where
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the people prayed, and heard the organ roaring over the marshes.  The
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sound of the organ roared over the marshes, but the song and prayers
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the people streamed up from the cathedral's highest tower like
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thin gold chains, and reached to Paradise, and up and down them went
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the angels from Paradise to the people, and from the people to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Paradise again.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then something akin to discontent troubled the Wild Thing for the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: first time since the making of the marshes; and the soft grey ooze
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the chill of the deep water seemed to be not enough, nor the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: first arrival from northwards of the tumultuous geese, nor the wild
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rejoicing of the wings of the wildfowl when every feather sings, nor
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the wonder of the calm ice that comes when the snipe depart and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beards the rushes with frost and clothes the hushed waste with a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mysterious haze where the sun goes red and low, nor even the dance
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the Wild Things in the marvellous night; and the little Wild
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thing longed to have a soul, and to go and worship God.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And when evensong was over and the lights were out, it went back
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: crying to its kith.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But on the next night, as soon as the images of the stars appeared
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the water, it went leaping away from star to star to the farthest
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: edge of the marshlands, where a great wood grew where dwelt the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Oldest of the Wild Things.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And it found the Oldest of Wild Things sitting under a tree,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sheltering itself from the moon.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the little Wild Thing said: 'I want to have a soul to worship
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: God, and to know the meaning of music, and to see the inner beauty
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the marshlands and to imagine Paradise.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the Oldest of the Wild Things said to it: 'What have we to do
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with God? We are only Wild Things, and of the kith of the Elf-folk.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But it only answered, 'I want to have a soul.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then the Oldest of the Wild Things said: 'I have no soul to give
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: you; but if you got a soul, one day you would have to die, and if
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: you knew the meaning of music you would learn the meaning of sorrow,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and it is better to be a Wild Thing and not to die.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So it went weeping away.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But they that were kin to the Elf-folk were sorry for the little
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Wild Thing; and though the Wild Things cannot sorrow long, having no
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: souls to sorrow with, yet they felt for awhile a soreness where
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their souls should be, when they saw the grief of their comrade.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So the kith of the Elf-folk went abroad by night to make a soul for
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the little Wild Thing.  And they went over the marshes till they came
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to the high fields among the flowers and grasses.  And there they
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gathered a large piece of gossamer that the spider had laid by
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: twilight; and the dew was on it.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Into this dew had shone all the lights of the long banks of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ribbed sky, as all the colours changed in the restful spaces of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: evening.  And over it the marvellous night had gleamed with all its
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stars.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then the Wild Things went with their dew-bespangled gossamer down to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the edge of their home.  And there they gathered a piece of the grey
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mist that lies by night over the marshlands.  And into it they put
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the melody of the waste that is borne up and down the marshes in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: evening on the wings of the golden plover.  And they put into it, too,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the mournful song that the reeds are compelled to sing before the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: presence of the arrogant North Wind.  Then each of the Wild Things
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gave some treasured memory of the old marshes, 'For we can spare
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it,' they said.  And to all this they added a few images of the stars
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that they gathered out of the water.  Still the soul that the kith of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the Elf-folk were making had no life.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then they put into it the low voices of two lovers that went walking
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the night, wandering late alone.  And after that they waited for
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dawn.  And the queenly dawn appeared, and the marsh-lights of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Wild Things paled in the glare, and their bodies faded from view;
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and still they waited by the marsh's edge.  And to them waiting came
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: over field and marsh, from the ground and out of the sky, the myriad
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: song of the birds.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: This, too, the Wild Things put into the piece of haze that they had
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gathered in the marshlands, and wrapped it all up in their
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dew-bespangled gossamer.  Then the soul lived.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And there it lay in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the hands of the Wild Things no larger than a hedgehog; and wonderful
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lights were in it, green and blue; and they changed ceaselessly,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: going round and round, and in the grey midst of it was a purple
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flare.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the next night they came to the little Wild Thing and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: showed her the gleaming soul.  And they said to her: 'If you must
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have a soul and go and worship God, and become a mortal and die,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: place this to your left breast a little above the heart, and it will
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: enter and you will become a human.  But if you take it you can never
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: be rid of it to become immortal again unless you pluck it out and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: give it to another; and we will not take it, and most of the humans
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have a soul already.  And if you cannot find a human without a soul
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: you will one day die, and your soul cannot go to Paradise, because
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it was only made in the marshes.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Far away the little Wild Thing saw
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the cathedral windows alight for evensong, and the song of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: people mounting up to Paradise, and all the angels going up and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down.  So it bid farewell with tears and thanks to the Wild Things of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the kith of Elf-folk, and went leaping away towards the green dry
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: land, holding the soul in its hands.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the Wild Things were sorry that it had gone, but could not be
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sorry long, because they had no souls.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: At the marsh's edge the little Wild Thing gazed for some moments
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: over the water to where the marsh-fires were leaping up and down,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and then pressed the soul against its left breast a little above the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heart.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Instantly it became a young and beautiful woman, who was cold and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: frightened.  She clad herself somehow with bundles of reeds, and went
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: towards the lights of a house that stood close by.  And she pushed
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: open the door and entered, and found a farmer and a farmer's wife
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sitting over their supper.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the farmer's wife took the little Wild Thing with the soul of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the marshes up to her room, and clothed her and braided her hair,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and brought her down again, and gave her the first food that she had
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ever eaten.  Then the farmer's wife asked many questions.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Where have you come from?' she said.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Over the marshes.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'From what direction?' said the farmer's wife.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'South,' said the little Wild Thing with the new soul.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'But none can come over the marshes from the south,' said the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: farmer's wife.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'No, they can't do that,' said the farmer.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'I lived in the marshes.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Who are you?' asked the farmer's wife.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'I am a Wild Thing, and have found a soul in the marshes, and we are
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: kin to the Elf-folk.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Talking it over afterwards, the farmer and his wife agreed that she
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: must be a gipsy who had been lost, and that she was queer with
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hunger and exposure.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So that night the little Wild Thing slept in the farmer's house, but

text: In a tavern of foul repute three men were lapping gin.  Their names
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

text: and I was lying on the warm, grassy slope of a valley in England.  It
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was a valley that I had known well when I was young, but I had
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not seen it now for many years.  Beside me stood the tall flower of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the mint; I saw the sweet-smelling thyme flower and one or two wild
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: strawberries.  There came up to me from fields below me the beautiful
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: smell of hay, and there was a break in the voice of the cuckoo.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: There was a feeling of summer and of evening and of lateness and of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sabbath in the air; the sky was calm and full of a strange colour,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the sun was low; the bells in the church in the village were all
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a-ring, and the chimes went wandering with echoes up the valley
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: towards the sun, and whenever the echoes died a new chime was born.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And all the people of the village walked up a stone-paved path under
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a black oak porch and went into the church, and the chimes stopped
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the people of the village began to sing, and the level sunlight
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shone on the white tombstones that stood all round the church.  Then
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there was a stillness in the village, and shouts and laughter came
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: up from the valley no more, only the occasional sound of the organ
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and of song.  And the blue butterflies, those that love the chalk,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came and perched themselves on the tall grasses, five or six
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sometimes on a single piece of grass, and they closed their wings
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and slept, and the grass bent a little beneath them.  And from the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: woods along the tops of the hills the rabbits came hopping out and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nibbled the grass, and hopped a little further and nibbled again,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the large daisies closed their petals up and the birds began
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to sing.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then the hills spoke, all the great chalk hills that I loved, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with a deep and solemn voice they said, 'We have come to you to say
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Goodbye.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then they all went away, and there was nothing again all round about
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: me upon every side.  I looked everywhere for something on which to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rest the eye.  Nothing.  Suddenly a low grey sky swept over me and a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: moist air met my face; a great plain rushed up to me from the edge
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the clouds; on two sides it touched the sky, and on two sides
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: between it and the clouds a line of low hills lay.  One line of hills
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: brooded grey in the distance, the other stood a patchwork of little
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: square green fields, with a few white cottages about it.  The plain
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was an archipelago of a million islands each about a yard square or
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: less, and everyone of them was red with heather.  I was back on the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Bog of Allen again after many years, and it was just the same as
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ever, though I had heard that they were draining it.  I was with an
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: old friend whom I was glad to see again, for they had told me that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he died some years ago.  He seemed strangely young, but what
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: surprised me most was that he stood upon a piece of bright green
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: moss which I had always learned to think would never bear.  I was
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: glad, too, to see the old bog again, and all the lovely things that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grew there--the scarlet mosses and the green mosses and the firm
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and friendly heather, and the deep silent water.  I saw a little
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stream that wandered vaguely through the bog, and little white
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shells down in the clear depths of it; I saw, a little way off, one
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the great pools where no islands are, with rushes round its
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: borders, where the duck love to come.  I looked long at that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: untroubled world of heather, and then I looked at the white cottages
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on the hill, and saw the grey smoke curling from their chimneys and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: knew that they burned turf there, and longed for the smell of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: burning turf again.  And far away there arose and came nearer the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: weird cry of wild and happy voices, and a flock of geese appeared
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that was coming from the northward.  Then their cries blended into
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: one great voice of exultation, the voice of freedom, the voice of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Ireland, the voice of the Waste; and the voice said 'Goodbye to you.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Goodbye!' and passed away into the distance; and as it passed, the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tame geese on the farms cried out to their brothers up above them
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that they were free.  Then the hills went away, and the bog and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sky went with them, and I was alone again, as lost souls are alone.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then there grew up beside me the red brick buildings of my first
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: school and the chapel that adjoined it.  The fields a little way off
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were full of boys in white flannels playing cricket.  On the asphalt
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: playing ground, just by the schoolroom windows, stood Agamemnon,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Achilles, and Odysseus, with their Argives armed behind them; but
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Hector stepped down out of a ground-floor window, and in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: schoolroom were all Priam's sons and the Achaeans and fair Helen;
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and a little farther away the Ten Thousand drifted across the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: playground, going up into the heart of Persia to place Cyrus on his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: brother's throne.  And the boys that I knew called to me from the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fields, and said 'Goodbye,' and they and the fields went away; and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the Ten Thousand said 'Goodbye,' each file as they passed me
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: marching swiftly, and they too disappeared.  And Hector and Agamemnon
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: said 'Goodbye,' and the host of the Argives and of the Achaeans; and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they all went away and the old school with them, and I was alone
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The next scene that filled the emptiness was rather dim: I was being
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: led by my nurse along a little footpath over a common in Surrey.  She
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was quite young.  Close by a band of gypsies had lit their fire, near
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: them their romantic caravan stood unhorsed, and the horse cropped
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grass beside it.  It was evening, and the gypsies muttered round
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their fire in a tongue unknown and strange.  Then they all said in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: English, 'Goodbye'. And the evening and the common and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: campfire went away.  And instead of this a white highway with
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: darkness and stars below it that led into darkness and stars, but at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the near end of the road were common fields and gardens, and there I
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stood close to a large number of people, men and women.  And I saw a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: man walking alone down the road away from me towards the darkness
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the stars, and all the people called him by his name, and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: man would not hear them, but walked on down the road, and the people
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: went on calling him by his name.  But I became irritated with the man
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: because he would not stop or turn round when so many people called
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him by his name, and it was a very strange name.  And I became weary
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of hearing the strange name so very often repeated, so that I made a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great effort to call him, that he might listen and that the people
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: might stop repeating this strange name.  And with the effort I opened
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: my eyes wide, and the name that the people called was my own name,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and I lay on the river's bank with men and women bending over me,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The argument that I had with my brother in his great lonely house
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: will scarcely interest my readers.  Not those, at least, whom I hope
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: may be attracted by the experiment that I undertook, and by the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: strange things that befell me in that hazardous region into which so
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lightly and so ignorantly I allowed my fancy to enter.  It was at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Oneleigh that I had visited him.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now Oneleigh stands in a wide isolation, in the midst of a dark
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gathering of old whispering cedars.  They nod their heads together
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when the North Wind comes, and nod again and agree, and furtively
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grow still again, and say no more awhile.  The North Wind is to them
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: like a nice problem among wise old men; they nod their heads over
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it, and mutter about it all together.  They know much, those cedars,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they have been there so long.  Their grandsires knew Lebanon, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the grandsires of these were the servants of the King of Tyre and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came to Solomon's court.  And amidst these black-haired children of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grey-headed Time stood the old house of Oneleigh.  I know not how
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: many centuries had lashed against it their evanescent foam of years;
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but it was still unshattered, and all about it were the things of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: long ago, as cling strange growths to some sea-defying rock.  Here,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: like the shells of long-dead limpets, was armour that men encased
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: themselves in long ago; here, too, were tapestries of many colours,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beautiful as seaweed; no modern flotsam ever drifted hither, no
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: early Victorian furniture, no electric light.  The great trade
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: routes that littered the years with empty meat tins and cheap novels
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were far from here.  Well, well, the centuries will shatter it and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: drive its fragments on to distant shores.  Meanwhile, while it yet
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stood, I went on a visit there to my brother, and we argued about
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ghosts.  My brother's intelligence on this subject seemed to me to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: be in need of correction.  He mistook things imagined for things
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: having an actual existence; he argued that second-hand evidence of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: persons having seen ghosts proved ghosts to exist.  I said that even
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: if they had seen ghosts, this was no proof at all; nobody believes
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that there are red rats, though there is plenty of first-hand
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: evidence of men having seen them in delirium.  Finally, I said I
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: would see ghosts myself, and continue to argue against their actual
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: existence.  So I collected a handful of cigars and drank several
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cups of very strong tea, and went without my dinner, and retired
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: into a room where there was dark oak and all the chairs were covered
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with tapestry; and my brother went to bed bored with our argument,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and trying hard to dissuade me from making myself uncomfortable.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: All the way up the old stairs as I stood at the bottom of them, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: as his candle went winding up and up, I heard him still trying to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: persuade me to have supper and go to bed.

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: It was a windy winter, and outside the cedars were muttering I know
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not what about; but I think that they were Tories of a school long
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dead, and were troubled about something new.  Within, a great damp
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: log upon the fireplace began to squeak and sing, and struck up a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: whining tune, and a tall flame stood up over it and beat time, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all the shadows crowded round and began to dance.  In distant
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: corners old masses of darkness sat still like chaperones and never
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: moved.  Over there, in the darkest part of the room, stood a door
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that was always locked.  It led into the hall, but no one ever used
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it; near that door something had happened once of which the family
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: are not proud.  We do not speak of it.  There in the firelight stood
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the venerable forms of the old chairs; the hands that had made their
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tapestries lay far beneath the soil, the needles with which they
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wrought were many separate flakes of rust.  No one wove now in that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: old room--no one but the assiduous ancient spiders who, watching
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by the deathbed of the things of yore, worked shrouds to hold their
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dust.  In shrouds about the cornices already lay the heart of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: oak wainscot that the worm had eaten out.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Surely at such an hour, in such a room, a fancy already excited by
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hunger and strong tea might see the ghosts of former occupants.  I
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: expected nothing less.  The fire flickered and the shadows danced,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is with the small hours had come upon me, and I had nearly abandoned
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of silk dresses that I had waited for and expected.  Then there

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: entered two by two the high-born ladies and their gallants of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Jacobean times.  They were little more than shadows--very
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

text: noses were to the ground sniffing, they went up to the lords and

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ladies of long ago and fawned about them disgustingly.  Their eyes
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were horribly bright, and ran down to great depths.  When I looked

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: into them I knew suddenly what these creatures were, and I was
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: poor ghosts! how many flights they must have attempted for two
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: me, they sprang up trying to reach my throat; and whenever their
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: claws touched me, horrible thoughts came into my mind and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: unutterable desires dominated my heart.  I planned bestial things as
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cunning.  A great red-eyed murder was among the foremost of those
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Suddenly it seemed to me good that I should kill my brother.  It
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seemed important to me that I should not risk being punished.  I
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: knew where a revolver was kept; after I had shot him, I would dress
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the body up and put flour on the face like a man that had been
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: acting as a ghost.  It would be very simple.  I would say that he had
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: frightened me--and the servants had heard us talking about ghosts.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: There were one or two trivialities that would have to be arranged,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but nothing escaped my mind.  Yes, it seemed to me very good that I
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: creature's eyes.  But one last effort as they dragged me down--'If
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

text: right angles.'

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sun.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I said to him: 'Who art thou?'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And he said:
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'I am named Nooz Wana, the Whelmer of Ships, and from the Straits of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Pondar Obed I am come, wherein it is my wont to vex the seas.  There
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I chased Leviathan with my hands when he was young and strong; often
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he slipped through my fingers, and away into the weed forests that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grow below the storms in the dusk on the floor of the sea; but at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: last I caught and tamed him.  For there I lurk upon the ocean's
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: floor, midway between the knees of either cliff, to guard the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Seas; and whenever the white sails of the tall ships come swelling
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their course, and are caught in the waters as I whirl them round my
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: head.  Then I draw in the waters of the Straits towards me and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: downwards, nearer and nearer to my terrible feet, and hear in my
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Once in every hundred years, for one day only, I go to rest myself
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Seas, and there the sailors may come upon content and long for
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: house, and all night long those whom fear kept awake could see his

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And still the dreams came flitting through the forest, and led men's
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: village, and told them that he had uttered his mightiest spell--a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by their marge.  And the hide of his back is of steel, and his under
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: parts are of iron; but along the midst of his back, over his spine,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there lies a narrow strip of unearthly steel.  This strip of steel is
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sacnoth, and it may be neither cleft nor molten, and there is
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nothing in the world that may avail to break it, nor even leave a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then sorrow fell upon Leothric, but the magician spoke on:
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: This is the tale of the vanquishing of The Fortress Unvanquishable,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Save For Sacnoth, and of its passing away, as it is told and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: believed by those who love the mystic days of old.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Others have said, and vainly claim to prove, that a fever came to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Allathurion, and went away; and that this same fever drove Leothric
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: into the marshes by night, and made him dream there and act
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: violently with a sword.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And others again say that there hath been no town of Allathurion,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and that Leothric never lived.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Peace to them.  The gardener hath gathered up this autumn's leaves.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Who shall see them again, or who wot of them? And who shall say what
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hath befallen in the days of long ago?
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord
