text: The Lord of Cities
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I came one day upon a road that wandered so aimlessly that it was
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: suited to my mood, so I followed it, and it led me presently among
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: deep woods.  Somewhere in the midst of them Autumn held his court,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sitting wreathed with gorgeous garlands; and it was the day before
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his annual festival of the Dance of Leaves, the courtly festival
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: upon which hungry Winter rushes mob-like, and there arise the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: furious cries of the North Wind triumphing, and all the splendour
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and grace of the woods is gone, and Autumn flees away, discrowned
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and forgotten, and never again returns.  Other Autumns arise, other
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Autumns, and fall before other Winters.  A road led away to the left,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but my road went straight on.  The road to the left had a trodden
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: appearance; there were wheel tracks on it, and it seemed the correct
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: way to take.  It looked as if no one could have any business with the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: road that led straight on and up the hill.  Therefore I went straight
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on and up the hill; and here and there on the road grew blades of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grass undisturbed in the repose and hush that the road had earned
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from going up and down the world; for you can go by this road, as
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: you can go by all roads, to London, to Lincoln, to the North of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Scotland, to the West of Wales, and to Wrellisford where roads end.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Presently the woods ended, and I came to the open fields and at the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: same moment to the top of the hill, and saw the high places of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Somerset and the downs of Wilts spread out along the horizon.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Suddenly I saw underneath me the village of Wrellisford, with no
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sound in its street but the voice of the Wrellis roaring as he
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tumbled over a weir above the village.  So I followed my road down
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: over the crest of the hill, and the road became more languid as I
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: descended, and less and less concerned with the cares of a highway.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Here a spring broke out in the middle of it, and here another. The
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: road never heeded.  A stream ran right across it, still it straggled
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on.  Suddenly it gave up the minimum property that a road should
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: possess, and, renouncing its connection with High Streets, its
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lineage of Piccadilly, shrank to one side and became an
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: unpretentious footpath.  Then it led me to the old bridge over the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stream, and thus I came to Wrellisford, and found after travelling
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in many lands a village with no wheel tracks in its street.  On the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: other side of the bridge, my friend the road struggled a few yards
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: up a grassy slope, and there ceased.  Over all the village hung a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great stillness, with the roar of the Wrellis cutting right across
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it, and there came occasionally the bark of a dog that kept watch
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: over the broken stillness and over the sanctity of that untravelled
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: road.  That terrible and wasting fever that, unlike so many plagues,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: comes not from the East but from the West, the fever of hurry, had
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not come here--only the Wrellis hurried on his eternal quest, but it
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was a calm and placid hurry that gave one time for song.  It was in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the early afternoon, and nobody was about.  Either they worked beyond
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the mysterious valley that nursed Wrellisford and hid it from the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: world, or else they secluded themselves within their old-time houses
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that were roofed with tiles of stone.  I sat down upon the old stone
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bridge and watched the Wrellis, who seemed to me to be the only
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: traveller that came from far away into this village where roads end,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and passed on beyond it.  And yet the Wrellis comes singing out of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: eternity, and tarries for a very little while in the village where
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: roads end, and passes on into eternity again; and so surely do all
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that dwell in Wrellisford.  I wondered as I leaned upon the bridge in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: what place the Wrellis would first find the sea, whether as he
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wound idly through meadows on his long quest he would suddenly
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: behold him, and, leaping down over some rocky cliff, take to him at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: once the message of the hills.  Or whether, widening slowly into some
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grand and tidal estuary, he would take his waste of waters to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sea and the might of the river should meet with the might of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: waves, like to two Emperors clad in gleaming mail meeting midway
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: between two hosts of war; and the little Wrellis would become a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: haven for returning ships and a setting-out place for adventurous
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: men.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: A little beyond the bridge there stood an old mill with a ruined
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: roof, and a small branch of the Wrellis rushed through its emptiness
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shouting, like a boy playing alone in a corridor of some desolate
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: house.  The mill-wheel was gone, but there lay there still great bars
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and wheels and cogs, the bones of some dead industry.  I know not
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: what industry was once lord in that house, I know not what retinue
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of workers mourns him now; I only know who is lord there today in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all those empty chambers.  For as soon as I entered, I saw a whole
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wall draped with his marvellous black tapestry, without price
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: because inimitable and too delicate to pass from hand to hand among
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: merchants.  I looked at the wonderful complexity of its infinite
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: threads, my finger sank into it for more than an inch without
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: feeling the touch; so black it was and so carefully wrought,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sombrely covering the whole of the wall, that it might have been
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: worked to commemorate the deaths of all that ever lived there, as
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: indeed it was.  I looked through a hole in the wall into an inner
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: chamber where a worn-out driving band went among many wheels, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there this priceless inimitable stuff not merely clothed the walls
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but hung from bars and ceiling in beautiful draperies, in marvellous
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: festoons.  Nothing was ugly in this desolate house, for the busy
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: artist's soul of its present lord had beautified everything in its
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desolation.  It was the unmistakable work of the spider, in whose
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: house I was, and the house was utterly desolate but for him, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: silent but for the roar of the Wrellis and the shout of the little
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stream.  Then I turned homewards; and as I went up and over the hill
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and lost the sight of the village, I saw the road whiten and harden
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and gradually broaden out till the tracks of wheels appeared; and it
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: went afar to take the young men of Wrellisford into the wide ways of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the earth--to the new West and the mysterious East, and into the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: troubled South.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And that night, when the house was still and sleep
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was far off, hushing hamlets and giving ease to cities, my fancy
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wandered up that aimless road and came suddenly to Wrellisford.  And
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it seemed to me that the travelling of so many people for so many
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: years between Wrellisford and John o' Groat's, talking to one
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: another as they went or muttering alone, had given the road a voice.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And it seemed to me that night that the road spoke to the river by
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Wrellisford bridge, speaking with the voice of many pilgrims.  And
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the road said to the river: 'I rest here.  How is it with you?'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the river, who is always speaking, said: 'I rest nowhere from
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: doing the Work of the World.  I carry the murmur of inner lands to
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sea, and to the abysses voices of the hills.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'It is I,' said the road, 'that do the Work of the World, and take
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from city to city the rumour of each.  There is nothing higher than
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Man and the making of cities.  What do you do for Man?'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the river said: 'Beauty and song are higher than Man.  I carry
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the news seaward of the first song of the thrush after the furious
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: retreat of winter northward, and the first timid anemone learns from
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: me that she is safe and that spring has truly come.  Oh but the song
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of all the birds in spring is more beautiful than Man, and the first
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: coming of the hyacinth more delectable than his face!  When spring is
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fallen upon the days of summer, I carry away with mournful joy at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: night petal by petal the rhododendron's bloom.  No lit procession of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: purple kings is nigh so fair as that.  No beautiful death of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: well-beloved men hath such a glory of forlornness.  And I bear far
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: away the pink and white petals of the apple-blossom's youth when the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: laborious time comes for his work in the world and for the bearing
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of apples.  And I am robed each day and every night anew with the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beauty of heaven, and I make lovely visions of the trees.  But Man!
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: What is Man? In the ancient parliament of the elder hills, when the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grey ones speak together, they say nought of Man, but concern
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: themselves only with their brethren the stars.  Or when they wrap
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: themselves in purple cloaks at evening, they lament some old
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: irreparable wrong, or, uttering some mountain hymn, all mourn the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: set of sun.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Your beauty,' said the road, 'and the beauty of the sky, and of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rhododendron blossom and of spring, live only in the mind of Man,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and except in the mind of Man the mountains have no voices.  Nothing
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is beautiful that has not been seen by Man's eye.  Or if your
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rhododendron blossom was beautiful for a moment, it soon withered
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and was drowned, and spring soon passes away; beauty can only live
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on in the mind of Man.  I bring thought into the mind of Man swiftly
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from distant places every day.  I know the Telegraph--I know him
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: well; he and I have walked for hundreds of miles together.  There is
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: no work in the world except for Man and the making of his cities.  I
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: take wares to and fro from city to city.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'My little stream in the field there,' said the river, 'used to make
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wares in that house for awhile once.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Ah,' said the road, 'I remember, but I brought cheaper ones from
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: distant cities.  Nothing is of any importance but making cities for
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Man.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'I know so little about him,' said the river, 'but I have a great
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: deal of work to do--I have all this water to send down to the sea;
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and then tomorrow or next day all the leaves of Autumn will be
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: coming this way.  It will be very beautiful.  The sea is a very, very
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wonderful place.  I know all about it; I have heard shepherd boys
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: singing of it, and sometimes before a storm the gulls come up.  It is
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a place all blue and shining and full of pearls, and has in it coral
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: islands and isles of spice, and storms and galleons and the bones of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Drake.  The sea is much greater than Man.  When I come to the sea, he
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: will know that I have worked well for him.  But I must hurry, for I
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have much to do.  This bridge delays me a little; some day I will
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: carry it away.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Oh, you must not do that,' said the road.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Oh, not for a long time,' said the river.  'Some centuries
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: perhaps--and I have much to do besides.  There is my song to sing, for
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: instance, and that alone is more beautiful than any noise that Man
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: makes.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'All work is for Man,' said the road, 'and for the building of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cities.  There is no beauty or romance or mystery in the sea except
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for the men that sail abroad upon it, and for those that stay at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: home and dream of them.  As for your song, it rings night and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: morning, year in, year out, in the ears of men that are born in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Wrellisford; at night it is part of their dreams, at morning it is
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the voice of day, and so it becomes part of their souls.  But the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: song is not beautiful in itself.  I take these men with your song in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their souls up over the edge of the valley and a long way off
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beyond, and I am a strong and dusty road up there, and they go with
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: your song in their souls and turn it into music and gladden cities.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But nothing is the Work of the World except work for Man.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'I wish I was quite sure about the Work of the World,' said the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stream; 'I wish I knew for certain for whom we work.  I feel almost
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sure that it is for the sea.  He is very great and beautiful.  I think
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that there can be no greater master than the sea.  I think that some
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: day he may be so full of romance and mystery and sound of sheep
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bells and murmur of mist-hidden hills, which we streams shall have
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: brought him, that there will be no more music or beauty left in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: world, and all the world will end; and perhaps the streams shall
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gather at the last, we all together, to the sea.  Or perhaps the sea
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: will give us at the last unto each one his own again, giving back
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all that he has garnered in the years--the little petals of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: apple-blossom and the mourned ones of the rhododendron, and our old
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: visions of the trees and sky; so many memories have left the hills.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But who may say? For who knows the tides of the sea?'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Be sure that it is all for Man,' said the road.  'For Man and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: making of cities.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Something had come near on utterly silent feet.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Peace, peace!' it said.  'You disturb the queenly night, who, having
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: come into this valley, is a guest in my dark halls.  Let us have an
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: end to this discussion.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: It was the spider who spoke.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'The Work of the World is the making of cities and palaces.  But it
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is not for Man.  What is Man? He only prepares my cities for me, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mellows them.  All his works are ugly, his richest tapestries are
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: coarse and clumsy.  He is a noisy idler.  He only protects me from
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mine enemy the wind; and the beautiful work in my cities, the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: curving outlines and the delicate weavings, is all mine.  Ten years
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to a hundred it takes to build a city, for five or six hundred more
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it mellows, and is prepared for me; then I inhabit it, and hide away
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all that is ugly, and draw beautiful lines about it to and fro.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: There is nothing so beautiful as cities and palaces; they are the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: loveliest places in the world, because they are the stillest, and so
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: most like the stars.  They are noisy at first, for a little, before I
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: come to them; they have ugly corners not yet rounded off, and coarse
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tapestries, and then they become ready for me and my exquisite work,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and are quite silent and beautiful.  And there I entertain the regal
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nights when they come there jewelled with stars, and all their train
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of silence, and regale them with costly dust.  Already nods, in a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: city that I wot of, a lonely sentinel whose lords are dead, who
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grows too old and sleepy to drive away the gathering silence that
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: infests the streets; tomorrow I go to see if he be still at his
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: post.  For me Babylon was built, and rocky Tyre; and still men build
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: my cities!  All the Work of the World is the making of cities, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all of them I inherit.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The Doom of La Traviata
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Evening stole up out of mysterious lands and came down on the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: streets of Paris, and the things of the day withdrew themselves and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hid away, and the beautiful city was strangely altered, and with it
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the hearts of men.  And with lights and music, and in silence and in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dark, the other life arose, the life that knows the night, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dark cats crept from the houses and moved to silent places, and dim
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: streets became haunted with dusk shapes.  At this hour in a mean
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: house, near to the Moulin Rouge, La Traviata died; and her death was
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: brought to her by her own sins, and not by the years of God.  But the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: soul of La Traviata drifted blindly about the streets where she had
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sinned till it struck against the wall of Notre Dame de Paris.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thence it rushed upwards, as the sea mist when it beats against a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cliff, and streamed away to Paradise, and was there judged.  And it
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seemed to me, as I watched from my place of dreaming, when La
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Traviata came and stood before the seat of judgment, that clouds
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came rushing up from the far Paradisal hills and gathered together
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: over the head of God, and became one black cloud; and the clouds
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: moved swiftly as shadows of the night when a lantern is swung in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hand, and more and more clouds rushed up, and ever more and more,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and, as they gathered, the cloud a little above the head of God
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: became no larger, but only grew blacker and blacker.  And the halos
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the saints settled lower upon their heads and narrowed and became
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: pale, and the singing of the choirs of the seraphim faltered and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sunk low, and the converse of the blessed suddenly ceased.  Then a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stern look came into the face of God, so that the seraphim turned
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: away and left Him, and the saints.  Then God commanded, and seven
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great angels rose up slowly through the clouds that carpet Paradise,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and there was pity on their faces, and their eyes were closed.  Then
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: God pronounced judgment, and the lights of Paradise went out, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the azure crystal windows that look towards the world, and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: windows rouge and verd, became dark and colourless, and I saw no
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: more.  Presently the seven great angels came out by one of Heaven's
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gates and set their faces Hellwards, and four of them carried the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: young soul of La Traviata, and one of them went on before and one of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: them followed behind.  These six trod with mighty strides the long and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dusty road that is named the Way of the Damned.  But the seventh flew
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: above them all the way, and the light of the fires of Hell that was
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hidden from the six by the dust of that dreadful road flared on the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: feathers of his breast.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Presently the seven angels, as they swept Hellwards, uttered speech.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'She is very young,' they said; and 'She is very beautiful,' they
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: said; and they looked long at the soul of La Traviata, looking not
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: at the stains of sin, but at that portion of her soul wherewith she
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had loved her sister a long while dead, who flitted now about an
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: orchard on one of Heaven's hills with a low sunlight ever on her
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: face, who communed daily with the saints when they passed that way
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: going to bless the dead from Heaven's utmost edge.  And as they
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: looked long at the beauty of all that remained beautiful in her soul
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they said: 'It is but a young soul;' and they would have taken her
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to one of Heaven's hills, and would there have given her a cymbal
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and a dulcimer, but they knew that the Paradisal gates were clamped
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and barred against La Traviata.  And they would have taken her to a
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: valley in the world where there were a great many flowers and a loud
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sound of streams, where birds were singing always and church bells
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rang on Sabbaths, only this they durst not do.  So they swept onwards
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nearer and nearer Hell.  But when they were come quite close and the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: glare was on their faces, and they saw the gates already divide and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prepare to open outwards, they said: 'Hell is a terrible city, and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: she is tired of cities;' then suddenly they dropped her by the side
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the road, and wheeled and flew away.  But into a great pink flower
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that was horrible and lovely grew the soul of La Traviata; and it
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had in it two eyes but no eyelids, and it stared constantly into the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: faces of all the passers-by that went along the dusty road to Hell;
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the flower grew in the glare of the lights of Hell, and withered
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but could not die; only, one petal turned back towards the heavenly
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hills as an ivy leaf turns outwards to the day, and in the soft and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: silvery light of Paradise it withered not nor faded, but heard at
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: times the commune of the saints coming murmuring from the distance,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and sometimes caught the scent of orchards wafted from the heavenly
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hills, and felt a faint breeze cool it every evening at the hour
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when the saints to Heaven's edge went forth to bless the dead.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But the Lord arose with His sword, and scattered His disobedient
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: angels as a thresher scatters chaff.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: On The Dry Land
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Over the marshes hung the gorgeous night with all his wandering
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bands of nomad stars, and his whole host of still ones blinked and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: watched.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Over the safe dry land to eastward, grey and cold, the first clear
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: pallor of dawn was coming up above the heads of the immortal gods.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then, as they neared at last the safety of the dry land, Love looked
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: at the man whom he had led for so long through the marshes, and saw
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that his hair was white, for it was shining in the pallor of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dawn.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then they stepped together on to the land, and the old man sat down
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: weary on the grass, for they had wandered in the marshes for many
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: years; and the light of the grey dawn widened above the heads of the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Love said to the old man, 'I will leave you now.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the old man made no answer, but wept softly.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then Love was grieved in his little careless heart, and he said:
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'You must not be sorry that I go, nor yet regret me, nor care for me
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: at all.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'I am a very foolish child, and was never kind to you, nor friendly.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I never cared for your great thoughts, or for what was good in you,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but perplexed you by leading you up and down the perilous marshes.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I was so heartless that, had you perished where I led you, it
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: would have been nought to me, and I only stayed with you because you
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were good to play with.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'And I am cruel and altogether worthless and not such a one as any
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: should be sorry for when I go, or one to be regretted, or even cared
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for at all.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And still the old man spoke not, but wept softly; and Love grieved
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bitterly in his kindly heart.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Love said: 'Because I am so small my strength has been concealed
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from you, and the evil that I have done.  But my strength is great,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and I have used it unjustly.  Often I pushed you from the causeway
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through the marshes, and cared not if you drowned.  Often I mocked
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: you, and caused others to mock you.  And often I led you among those
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that hated me, and laughed when they revenged themselves upon you.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'So weep not, for there is no kindness in my heart, but only murder
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and foolishness, and I am no companion for one so wise as you, but
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: am so frivolous and silly that I laughed at your noble dreams and
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hindered all your deeds.  See now, you have found me out, and now you
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: will send me away, and here you will live at ease, and, undisturbed,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have noble dreams of the immortal gods.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'See now, here is dawn and safety, and _there_ is darkness and peril.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Still the old man wept softly.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then Love said: 'Is it thus with you?' and his voice was grave now
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and quiet.  'Are you so troubled?  Old friend of so many years, there
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is grief in my heart for you.  Old friend of perilous ventures, I
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: must leave you now.  But I will send my brother soon to you--my
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: little brother Death.  And he will come up out of the marshes to you,
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and will not forsake you, but will be true to you as I have not been
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: true.'
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And dawn grew brighter over the immortal gods, and the old man
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: smiled through his tears, which glistened wondrously in the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: increasing light.  But Love went down to the night and to the
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: marshes, looking backward over his shoulder as he went, and smiling
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beautifully about his eyes.  And in the marshes whereunto he went, in
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the midst of the gorgeous night, and under the wandering bands of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nomad stars, rose shouts of laughter and the sounds of the dance.
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And after a while, with his face towards the morning, Death out of
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the marshes came up tall and beautiful, and with a faint smile
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shadowy on his lips, and lifted in his arms the lonely man, being
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gentle with him, and, murmuring with his low deep voice an ancient
title: The Sword of Welleran and Other Stories
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: song, carried him to the morning to the gods.
